messageBody:
Jon,

Thanks for the comments... I just read (and printed for my office) a
copy of the pretty Lord's Prayer. It is beautiful... (by the way,
did you mean <Hos> for "those"? My dialect would pronounce it
<HOz>.

In the modifictions I made last night, I realy did very little other
than try to space out the characters close to where they were in your
early version... I reshaped a couple of the letters to look a little
more like the Read handbook, but not many. I still do not have the
spacing correct... Using the font freeware I downloaded last night,
all I could find to really separate the letters was autometrics.
Just expanding the right edge of the characters alone did not cut
it. Unfortunately, the space around a t looks too big, and to the
right of a <w> and a <T> looks too little. And I do not understand
why Word seems to do this differently than MS Paint, for example.

Yes, I agree that major changes to the keyboard would not be a good
idea. I read your original comments on wanting to make the font
accessable to Shavian writers. My only significant change is to use
the <cap> W. It seemed to be a not very drastic evolutionary change
to highlight two of the major changes between Shavian and
Quickscript. It was also in partial answer to a critique I had seen
of the use of the left single quote for the wheat character being
hard on touch typists.

I offered the Junior font as only a small modification from your
senior version. It turns out it was only a retroversion! How
interesting!

I also understand the need for artsy lettering for special
occasions... but believe there is a real use for a more legible
version of quickscript closer to your original.

In Shavian there are a half dozen fonts which are variously readable
and preferable to individuals. I believe there is room for parallel
development of several Quickscript fonts as well.

Besides, it was fun to quickly try my hand at mofifying a font... My
first.

Rick

--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "Jon Zuck" <frimmin@e...> wrote:
> You're absolutely right, Rick. Jerome went through quite a bit of
evolution,
> and at first I was quite hesitant to go the distance of the half-
letters,
> and all. However, Paige convinced me, rightly, that there should be
a font
> that could emulate the full Senior Quickscript capabilities,
particularly
> when presenting its virtues to the Shavian community, which already
had a
> non-cursive Shavian font.
>
> I've uploaded to this group a copy of the poster of the Lord's
Prayer which
> I uploaded a few hours after my initial upload of Jerome. You can
see the
> difference: Junior Quickscriptish, very easy-to-read, etc.
>
> The thing is that there are really three Shavian alphabets: Shavian,
> Junior,and Senior. I think most people who are not adverse to
cursive
> writing :-) will eventually find Senior the more preferable one for
personal
> handwriting, which is the most practical use for a semi-private
alphabet
> that only a handful of people can read. But for the computer, in
English, we
> usually only use cursive fonts for art, titles, special emphasis,
and the
> feeling of a "personal touch." On the other hand, many languages
of world
> use connected, cursive letters: Hindi, Bengali, Arabic, Aramaic. I
felt
> after much correspondence with Paige that Read was clearly touting
the more
> cursive capabilities of Senior QA, which should connect.
>
> But thanks for giving us again a Junior font. It is more legible,
more
> suitable for screen.
>
> As long as all there's interest in all three alphabets, fonts for
all three
> should be avail. My only concern is the minor changes to the
mapping. We
> don't need three mappings. I think a Read-based mapping is
desireable, but
> on the other hand so is backward compatibility to Shavian--not so
much to
> lure them over, but to use their transliteration programs, which is
why I
> kept it in Jerome. (Bad as their mapping is, the fact that they
created a
> standard and built upon it is great.)
>
> BTW, I realized that my key to the Second Shaw Alphabet, originally
posted
> to the Shavian group wasn't on the files in this group and the
Shavian's
> copy was corrupted. I fixed it and posted it to both.
>
>
> Shalom v'Tovah,
>
> Jon
> http://surf.to/frimmin
>
> It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
> always do that which impels you most to love.
>
> --St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle

I also understand the need for artsy lettering for special

In Shavian there are a half dozen fonts which are variously readable 
and preferable to individuals.  I believe there is room for parallel

Besides, it was fun to quickly try my hand at mofifying a font... My

Rick
